Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the most inhospitable place on Earth, two men are using small pickaxes to gather samples at the base of a glacier face.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Charles. We've got enough samples, surely.
This isn't ice. This is something else. Have a look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He lifts a round object of about six inches diameter out of the snow.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
I don't know. Let's get it back to camp.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The remaining ice and snow is being carefully removed from the object.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Animal, vegetable, or mineral?
Vegetable.
Yes, that's what we thought.
The cutaneous creasing is unmistakable. When it's properly thawed out I can confirm it with a cytology test.
The skin looks as hard as iron.
Yes, it is a bit of a cannonball. How deep in the permafrost was it?
I guess about the ninth layer.
That means it's been there for oh, twenty thousand years? Well, what do you make of it, John?
Nothing at all yet. MOBERLEY Oh, and I thought you were meant to be a botanist.
I've not seen anything remotely like it.
It looks tropical to me, like a gourd.
Oh rubbish, Charles. If it's from the late Pleistocene period, it can't be tropical. It's a few million years since this part of Antarctica was rainforest.
That's the accepted theory. Discoveries like this have destroyed accepted theories before now. Isn't that right, John?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson touches the object with his bare fingers.

Dialogue.Line: John?
Hmm? Sorry.
Is something wrong?
Don't you feel it?
Feel what?
I don't know. There's something odd. Something. You don't feel it?
That must be that rice pudding you had for lunch.
I'm not joking. It's alive. That's it, it's alive.
Are you serious?
Yes.
How can you tell?
I don't know, but I'm certain that this is a living organism.
Yes, well, I think we should have some coffee.
Coffee and a game of three-handed crib. Good idea. Come on.
I'll transmit pictures to London. They might have some idea.
John, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In London, at the World Ecology Bureau, a bureaucrat has a visitor in his rather cramped office.

Dialogue.Line: Sir Colin insists that I show you these photographs which have just been received from my expedition.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is sitting on Dunbar's desk, playing with his yoyo.

Dialogue.Line: Personally, I don't think you can help us.
Don't you. Well.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dunbar gives him the file.

Dialogue.Line: Do sit down, Mister Dunbar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: With the Doctor blocking the way to his own chair, Dunbar sits in the guest seat.

Dialogue.Line: These pictures have baffled all the experts. The only reasonable explanation seems to be that the pod is from some extinct species of plant.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sits in Dunbar's chair with his feet on the desk.

Dialogue.Line: Have you considered an alternative explanation?
Name one.
Well, that it might have originated in outer space.
My dear Doctor, if you've seen anything like that before, you must have a very powerful telescope.
Mister Dunbar, how long is it since there was vegetation in Antarctica?

I thought you were the expert in these matters. Well, as a matter of fact, that's one of the things our expedition is trying to discover. It was found fairly deep in the permafrost, say twenty thirty thousand years under the ice.
Shush. It might still be ticking.
What?
A time-bomb, Mister Dunbar, a time-bomb. Are you in contact with the expedition?
My superior, Sir Colin Thackeray has a daily video link. Ten minutes of satellite time.
Good. Tell them to keep a constant guard upon the pod, and not to touch it till I arrive.
You're leaving immediately?
Why not? I've got my toothbrush. Remember, no touch pod. Could be dangerous. (The Doctor leaves, brandishing his toothbrush. Dunbar picks up the telephone.)
Sir Colin? Dunbar here. That chap you called in from UNIT. Is he quite sane?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson is measuring the pod's diameter.

Dialogue.Line: Incredible. Charles?
Yes?
Come in here a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winlett enters.

Dialogue.Line: What's up?
It's growing.
Eh?
It's grown five centimetres since this morning.
Are you sure?
Check it yourself if you don't believe me.
But it doesn't seem possible.
I knew there was still life there. I said so, didn't I?
But it's just a pod. I mean, no root system. How can it grow without feeding?
Sunlight, Charles. Ultra-violet radiation.
But plants need nitrogen.
I believe this is fundamentally different. We may be cultivating something that's going to shatter all our ideas about plant growth.
Yes, well, don't get carried away, John. Remember what London said.
What do you mean?
About leaving this thing alone.
Until this Doctor character arrives, why should we? It's our pod.
John, we're working for the World Ecology Bureau.
Oh, he's probably some old crank that Thackeray's dug up out of retirement. He'll have no more idea about the pod than we have.
We'll soon find out. He's due in tomorrow.
And who needs him. It's our discovery. The less said about it the better.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mansion is played by Athelhampton House, Dorset. The butler shows Dunbar into a part of Harrison Chase's mansion which is given over to the cultivation of tropical plants. The master of the house wears black leather gloves at all times.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Dunbar of the World Ecology Bureau, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think I've had the pleasure. And what is your Bureau doing about bonsai?
Bonsai, Mister Chase?
Mutilation and torture, Mister Dunbar. The hideous, grotesque Japanese practice of miniaturising shrubs and trees. What is your Bureau doing about that?
Well, I

No answer. You are concerned about the fate of the blue whale, and the natterjack toad, but the loveliest, most defenceless part of creation, the great kingdom of plant life receives no protection at all.
We try to conserve all the endangered species.
I'm delighted to hear that, Mister Dunbar. Of course you know of my concern, my mission, to protect the plant life of Mother Earth?
I do, Mister Chase. Which is why I've come to show you something. A totally new kind of plant.
Hybrids. A crime against nature
No, not a hybrid. It's a mysterious, unidentified pod recently discovered by one of our expeditions.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dunbar hands Chase the photographs.

Dialogue.Line: Where was this found?
There's a theory that it's floated through space from some other biosphere. The really important thing is, it may be still viable and able to germinate.
Mister Dunbar, I asked you where this pod was found.
In the Antarctic. Now, in our violent and uncertain world, Mister Chase, anything could happen. Such a valuable specimen could easily disappear for a price.
Where in the Antarctic? I should want to know the precise location.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dunbar gives Chase an envelope. Chase then goes over to an intercom system.

Dialogue.Line: Hargreaves?
Yes, sir?
You and Mister Scorby please.
Certainly, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase opens the envelope.

Dialogue.Line: X marks the spot.
Forethought and initiative, Mister Dunbar. Two excellent attributes. We shall meet again very soon to discuss your remuneration.
You're very kind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a knock on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves and Scorby enter. Everyone say Hi to  John Challis, before he became Boycie in Only Fools.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, sir?
Hargreaves, show Mister Dunbar out.
This way, Mister Dunbar.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves and Dunbar leave.

Dialogue.Line: You wanted to see me, Mister Chase?
Yes, Scorby. I'm sending you on a little errand, and I want you to take Mister Keeler with you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winlett is sitting near the pod, but has dozed off. He wakes again and takes a sip of his drink, puts the mug down and closes his eyes again. The pod opens and closes briefly, then opens fully. A tendril comes out and grabs Winlett's arm. He gets up and tries to get to the door, but he collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Derek!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson gets off his bunk.

Dialogue.Line: Was that Charles?
What? What's happening?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go along the corridor to the lab module.

Dialogue.Line: Charles?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He touches Winlett and he rolls onto his back, showing us his eyes staring out from a leaf-green face.

Dialogue.Line: This telex from Stevenson. What do you make of it?
(reads) Pod carries infection. Winlett seriously ill. Medicaid needed urgently. Could have been more informative, Sir Colin.
He probably doesn't know any more. I have ordered Medical Team to go to the base, but I understand weather conditions are bad. It's bound to take at least a day or two.
The people from UNIT should be arriving now. Perhaps they can help.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A helicopter lands.

Dialogue.Line: Hello! So you made it. Welcome to the loneliest spot on Earth. You must be the Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is in his usual clothes, while Sarah is in furs.

Dialogue.Line: Yes.
We were expecting someone much older.
I'm only seven hundred and forty nine. I used to be even younger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The helicopter leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Derek Moberley.
Sarah Jane Smith, the young Doctor's assistant.
How many of you live here?
Anything up to a dozen, but of course we're down to three at the moment. Let's get inside.
Yes.
Where are the others?
Out at South Bend, not sixty miles away, measuring the ice cap. If they're getting this kind of weather they're welcome to it. Come on.
How do you stand it?
Oh, sometimes it gets quite warm. Ten degrees below freezing.
Crikey, I feel as though I've got frostbite already.
I'll get you something hot to drink in a tick. Er, are you okay dressed like that? You don't seem to notice the cold.
I haven't come ten thousand miles to discuss the weather, Mister Moberley. Can I see the sick man?
Yes, of course. Down this way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winlett is very green now, and twitching under the sheet.

Dialogue.Line: He seems to be conscious, but he hasn't spoken a word since last night.
What's his body temperature?
Well, that's the amazing thing. I've been trying to keep him warm but it's dropping hourly.
And the pulse rate?
His body temperature is forty six, his pulse rate is eighteen a minute. I'm no medical expert, but on those figures he should be dead, shouldn't he?
I wonder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls back the sheet. Winlett's body is covered in green tendrils.

Dialogue.Line: Good grief! It wasn't like that an hour ago.
Then it's accelerating. How long before a medical team arrives?
Well, it's difficult to say in these conditions. Hopefully tomorrow.
I don't think that's going to be soon enough, Mister Stevenson.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah is breathing on her fingers to bring them back to life. Moberley brings her a mug.

Dialogue.Line: There, that ought to warm you up.
Thanks.
Better?
Mmm. So, you say you just found this pod lying there empty.
Yes, and Charles in that state. Now does that make any kind of sense to you?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A blue light on the wall flashes and beeps.

Dialogue.Line: Would you excuse me?
Yes.
Radio.
Oh, sure.
Have you any idea what it can be, Doctor?
Yes, that's why I came here.
I thought you came here to see the pod.
Exactly. Before anything happened. Unfortunately, it already has. Where's the lab?
I'll show you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Moberley is on the radio.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, Mike, but try to get something moving. His condition's pretty desperate. Over.
Understood. Out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson and the Doctor enter.

Dialogue.Line: Bad news, John. That was Mike Wilson at South Bend. The medical team's turned back.
What about Charles? Did you tell them how bad he is?

They were in white-out conditions and their Snow Cat's fallen into a crevasse. But Mike is in touch with the Royal Marine Survival Team. They might be able to help. They'll try again as soon as the weather lifts.
That'll be too late. He's dying, isn't he, Doctor?
No.
I thought you said in the sickbay
It's more serious than death, Mister Stevenson. He's changing form.
Changing form?
Yes. We need a blood test.
I'm a zoologist. I could prepare a specimen slide if it'll help?
Yes, it would help, thank you.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Moberley leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Pod.
It's over here.
Why did it open? Why?
Well, that, that could be my fault. It was frozen stiff when we took it out of the ice. I was certain there was still life there. I put in under a lamp and it started to expand.
Mister Stevenson, what you have done could result in the total destruction of all life on this planet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Moberley draws a syringe of red blood from Winlett.

Dialogue.Line: Charles? We're trying our best, Charles. Help's on its way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the base of the glacier, the Doctor is digging in the snow.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Doctor, what are we looking for?
Are you sure this is the place, Stevenson?
Yes, and if you told us what you were doing, perhaps we could help.
Yes, just as I thought.
Another pod!
How did you? Will there be any more?
No. They travel in pairs, like policeman.
What are we going to do with it, buy it a truncheon?
No. Take it into custody and keep it in the freezer.
Well, that ought to keep it cool.
Who sold you that, an Eskimo?
I know a freezer seems superfluous out here, but we do need it to keep snow samples in until they're analysed.
Doctor?
Hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Moberley is using a microscope.

Dialogue.Line: Take a look at this blood sample.
How's Winlett?
Winlett? He's barely recognisable. It's as if he's turning into some sort of a hideous monster.
That's exactly what is happening, Moberley.
Yes, but there must be an answer.
If you can just increase the magnification. Ah! Yes. Take a look at that.
These aren't blood platelets.
Do you recognise them?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson looks down the microscope.

Dialogue.Line: Schizophytes.
Exactly.
I don't believe it. It's not possible.
Would someone mind explaining what these schizophytes are, please?
The smallest known living organisms. Plant bacteria.
Plant bacteria in someone's bloodstream?
Interesting, isn't it? A human being whose blood is turning into vegetable soup.
Listen.
That's very low by the sound of it.
It's the medical aircraft. Quick, Derek, get the landing strip lights on.
They won't see anything in this blizzard.
Should we come out and help you?
No, John and I know our way around out there. It's easy to get lost.
Okay.
You ready?
Ready.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson and Moberley leave.

Dialogue.Line: Will they be able to help that man?
I don't know, Sarah. He's halfway towards becoming a Krynoid.
Krynoid?
Yes. A progression of the pod.
So you recognised it.
Yes, I was fairly certain when I saw the photographs. Now I'm sure.
Well, what is a Krynoid? I mean, what does it do?
I suppose you could call it a galactic weed, except it's deadlier than any weed you know.
In what way?
Well, on most planets, the animals eat the vegetation, hmm?
Mmm hmm.
On planets where the Krynoid gets established, the vegetation eats the animals.
But that's terrifying.
Yes.
Well, how did it get through space?
An obvious question. I wish I knew the answer. Possibly their planet of origin is turbulent from time to time, any internal explosions could cause surface matter to go shooting into space.
So what do we do about Winlett?
I'm thinking Sarah, I'm thinking.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Moberley and Stevenson help two more men into the Research station.

Dialogue.Line: Down this way here.
Right, into the chair. There you are.
Let me take that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah takes a rucksack.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, sit yourselves down.
Come on, sit down over here.
Brandy, Derek?
Right.
Is this the medical team?
They were flying a private plane.
They just got themselves lost. Here, brandy.
Thanks.
Sorry to be such a nuisance.
We were nearly out of fuel when we saw your lights.
You were very lucky. Lights are few and far between out here.
I'd like to take another look at the patient.
What, now?
Now. Yes, come on.
You just relax and thaw out.
Right, thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Sarah, Moberley and Stevenson leave.

Dialogue.Line: Do you think they swallowed it? If they start asking too many questions
Why worry, Keeler? What can they do?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Winlett is no longer human apart from an eye, nose and mouth.

Dialogue.Line: That's horrible. Horrible.
The process is almost complete.
We can do nothing except just watch it happen.
There is something you can do, but it's drastic.
Well, what?
Amputate the arm.
What good would that do? Can't you see the infection's all over his body?
Yes, but the arm's the source of the infection. It might stop it spreading.
You say might. What you mean is, you don't know.
Well of course I don't know! But it'd give you a breathing space while you try and find an antidote. That's a chance worth taking, isn't it?
And who's going to perform this operation?
Oh you are, Moberley. You're the only one who can.
But I'm not a surgeon. What about you? You're a doctor.
You must help yourselves.
He's not a doctor of medicine. Stevenson's a botanist, you're a zoologist. Ask yourself who's most qualified among us.
But I can't operate on Winlett. It's absurd!
Oh, at least you could try. You studied physiology, you know how to handle a scalpel.
To dissect dead specimens, yes, but Charles is a human being.
He won't be much longer if you don't operate! Look, have you got a medical kit?
We've a full medical kit in the lab.
Well? Well, what about it? You're his last chance.
Derek, we'll help you in every way we can.
I'll do my best.
You're a good man, Moberley. Come on, let's get started.
Right.
Hot towels.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all leave. Winlett sits up.

Dialogue.Line: I'll take these down to the sickbay and start setting up.
You'll need more lights in there.
I can fix that.
Winlett's still got a chance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Leaving Moberley for dead, Green Winlett heads out into the blizzard.
Scorby takes a case from underneath a bunk, and opens it to reveal a rifle and bullets inside.

Dialogue.Line: You'd think butter wouldn't melt in her mouth. Keep watch.
What're you doing, Scorby?
I don't like guns in the wrong hands.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby starts to dismantle the firing mechanism of the rifle.

Dialogue.Line: There's no need for that. They're not going to try and shoot us.
I'd rather not give them the chance. I said keep watch.
I wish you'd stop behaving like some cheap gangster. All we've come here for is to confirm that this pod is something unusual, that's all.
You don't think we're going to fly back empty-handed, do you?
But, we can't. Scorby! We'd never get away with it.
Are you a betting man, Keeler?
Now just a minute. This is the first you've said. I want to know exactly what it is you're planning.
All right, Keeler. Tomorrow, we did a nice big hole in the snow. Big enough for, say, five bodies. We fill it up, we take the pod, we fly home. No witnesses, nothing. Just another lost expedition.
You're mad. You're mad. You're mad. I'm not doing that. Oh, no.
You'll do it, Keeler. You'll do exactly as you're told. Otherwise we'll just make the hole a little bigger.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Click. Scorby was pointing the empty rifle at Keeler's head.
Sarah comes along the corridor and shuts the outer door, then goes around the corner to discover Moberley.

Dialogue.Line: Ready, Stevenson.
I'm sure

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah enters.

Dialogue.Line: I think Moberley's dead.
What?
This way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks at the body outside then enters to look at the empty bed. Stevenson follows.

Dialogue.Line: Did you see his face? Where's he gone?
He left after killing Moberley.
I don't believe it. You mean to say Charles did that?
Not Charles, the alien.
Alien?
Not of this world, Stevenson. I told you he was changing form. Already his mind's been taken over. Very soon his entire body will alter.
Into a Krynoid.
Yes. There'll be a transition period, a grotesque parody of the human form. By now, Winlett himself no longer exists and we must destroy what he's become.
Scorby, someone's coming.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby puts the rifle case back under the bunk. Stevenson and Sarah enter to get their outdoor clothes.

Dialogue.Line: You okay?
Yeah, a lot better, thanks. What's the trouble?
We're going out.
You're joking. In this weather?
Yes, Mister Scorby, in this weather.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson gets the rifle from its case.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, Stevenson. We don't have much time.
Ready, Doctor.
I hope that's the answer. Stay warm.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah, Stevenson and the Doctor leave.

Dialogue.Line: What the devil's going on?
What do you think I am, a mind reader? Anyway, come on. Now's our chance.
What do you mean? What do you mean? What do you mean? Do what?
To find the pod.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In Chase's mansion, an old English room with lots of oak panelling and a long case clock ticking in the background. Botanical paintings hang on the walls.

Dialogue.Line: I tell you something has happened out there. We've had a telex message saying an infection has broken out.
Infection? What sort of infection?
Apparently a virus conveyed by the pod. Now, if you get that pod, you'll probably have to take precautions.
If? There's no question of if. I have sent my most efficient man.
To Antarctica?
Yes. It will be easier to acquire the pod there rather than wait for its arrival in England and the resultant publicity. By that time it will be better protected than the Crown Jewels.
You're going well outside the law, Mister Chase.
I understand policemen are few and far between in the Antarctic.
Look, if there are any repercussions, have I your word you'll preserve my anonymity.
Don't worry, I always take care of my employees. It wouldn't do if a public servant of your standing were found betraying trust and selling secrets, would it.
No. On the other hand, I took up a career hoping to reach the top, but I've seen time-serving nonentities promoted over my head.
Yes, it must be most galling. The only alternative is to seek other forms of reward, which you have most sensibly done. I think you will find this is the amount we agreed for your, er, help.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase opens a briefcase on a side table. It is full of banknotes.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it's most generous.
A fair exchange, Dunbar. You want money, and I want that pod.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The thing that was Winlett has arrived at a building. A little later, the Doctor and Co look down on it from a ridge.

Dialogue.Line: What's that down there?
It's our generator plant.
Why so far from base?
Safety measure. It's a new fuel cell system being tested out here for the first time.
Let's take a look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby is ransacking a cupboard and making a lot of mess.

Dialogue.Line: You're supposed to be the botanist. Where would you keep this pod?
I don't know. I suppose it must be here somewhere. Careful, that valuable.
So what? There'll be nobody left to use it after we're finished.

Dialogue.Character: (And drops the equipment on the floor. The radio crackles into life. RADIO [OC]
Dialogue.Line: This is South Bend calling Camp Five. Come in, Camp Five. Over. KEELER: Scorby, what do we do? RADIO [OC]: This is South Bend calling Camp Five. Come in, Camp Five. Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby picks up the handset.

Dialogue.Line: Camp Five receiving you. Over.
Is that you, Derek?
Er, yes. Come in, South Bend.
The weather's clearing this end. The marines'll get the medic through as soon as possible.
Have they left yet?
They're leaving right now.
Look, cancel them, will you? We don't need them any more. Everything's under control here.
Hello? Is that you, Derek? Hello? Hello, Derek, is that you? Derek?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby pulls the aerial out of the back of the transceiver.

Dialogue.Line: It left the place in a blizzard. It'll try to find shelter somewhere.
I don't think this has been disturbed.
It's as well to make sure.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson unbolts the door.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Scorby, I think I've found it. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler has found the tray with the opened pod case on it.

Dialogue.Line: Now, that's the pod in Dunbar's photograph, but
Somebody's cut it open.
No, no, no, no, no. No, this wasn't cut. This must have germinated.
What do you mean, germinated?
I mean that this pod has opened as part of its natural cycle to release a shoot or something.
Yeah, but its the actual plant that Chase wants, right?
Right.
Well, we'd better find it, then, hadn't we, and quick.
No, I'm afraid Winlett must have collapsed somewhere.
Don't you ever listen, Stevenson? Winlett, Winlett, Winlett. Winlett as a man no longer exists.
All right then, he's a plant or a vegetable or whatever he is now. He's going to have even less resistance to cold, isn't he?
You know, I find this very hard to take. You're telling me that these things are inimical to the whole of animal creation?
Inimicable? They're lethal.
How do you know?
Never mind how I know, Stevenson, just take it from me. On any planet where the Krynoid gets established, all animal life is extinguished.
There's no danger now, is there? I mean, we've got the second pod in the freezer, and Winlett
Winlett?
The Krynoid is very likely frozen stiff under the snow somewhere.
I hope you're right.
So do I.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They head back to base. The Krynoid watches them go.
Scorby uncovers Moberley's corpse lying on the bed.

Dialogue.Line: Good grief! Look at that mark, Scorby. What could have caused that? That's the man who
Yeah, I know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krynoid bursts into the Generator plant.

Dialogue.Line: I'll be with you in a moment. I want to check something.
In here, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The figure on the bed is covered over again.

Dialogue.Line: Whatever you do, don't touch him. Don't touch him.
Get your hands up. Turn around, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby is behind the door, holding a pistol. The Doctor does a full 360 turn.

Dialogue.Line: Facing this way.
Have we annoyed you or something?
Shut up. Okay, start talking.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart had perfect pitch.
What happened to him?
Who, Wolfgang Amadeus? Oh, him. Oh, he died.
How?
We gathered that.
It happened because of a pod.
The pod?
Look, Doctor, there's already one corpse in here. I can easily double that number.
Look, he's telling you the
Stay where you are.
There's been an accident. One of the men was infected.
By the pod?
He went mad.
Yes, you could say he's not quite himself.
Where is he now?
We don't know. Somewhere out there.
Oh, you mean you have a homicidal maniac on the loose?
Oh, much more dangerous than that, and he's desperate for food and warmth. There's only one place he can find food and warmth.
You mean this camp.
It's a comforting thought, isn't it. I think we should lock all the doors and windows.
What are we going to do, Scorby?
Easy. I think it's time we got some real answers. But not in here. Why don't we make ourselves a little more comfortable? Come on, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler ties the Doctor and Sarah to chairs.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, that'll do. Watch the door. Now then, Doctor, let's have the truth. Where's the plant that came out of the pod?
That grew in the bed that was part of the garden close to the house that Jack
Jack built.
I'm not a patient man, Doctor.
Well, your candour does you credit. However, you're too late.
What do you mean?
Odd things have been happening. Odd and dangerous. I don't thing you'd understand.
Try me.
All right. At its simplest, the man who went mad is no longer a man in any sense you'd recognise.
Well, if he's not a man, what is he?
An alien lifeform.
I said I wanted some straight answers, Doctor.
Doctor?
Scorby! Somebody's coming.
Doctor? Miss Smith? Where are you?
In here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson enters.

Dialogue.Line: Come and join the party.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson raises the rifle.

Dialogue.Line: Drop that gun. I said, drop that gun!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Click. The rifle does not fire.

Dialogue.Line: Not very friendly, are we.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby pulls the rifle out of Stevenson's hands and sends him sprawling at the Doctor's feet.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening?
For some reason, these two want to get their hands on the pod.
(sotto) The pod's still safe? They haven't taken it out

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor nudges Stevenson with his knee.

Dialogue.Line: What did you say? Taken it out? Taken it out of where?
They've got a second pod.
Then we're not going back empty handed, are we? Where is it?
Oh, don't be a bigger fool than you already are. Don't you understand anything? It's dangerous.
I asked you a question, Doctor. Where is the pod?

Dialogue.Character: (The Doctor gazes levelly at the gun barrel, so Scorby puts it to Stevenson's head instead. SCORBY
Dialogue.Line: Where is it? Stubborn pair, aren't you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah's turn to be threatened.

Dialogue.Line: This time I'm not joking.
It's in the freezer.
That's better. You show me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby grabs Stevenson and offers a second gun to Keeler.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, watch these two.
No, no, no, I don't want it.
I said, watch them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler takes the gun.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson and Scorby leave.

Dialogue.Line: Don't worry, you're all right with us. We won't hurt you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson takes the second pod out of the freezer.

Dialogue.Line: Bring it here. Are there any more?
No, this is unique now. Priceless, as you are no doubt aware.
So what's to stop this breaking open like the other one?
It's quite safe at this temperature.
Well, it's going on a little journey. You must have something here to keep it cool.
We have thermal containers.
Get one. There's something I don't quite understand. Where does the power come from to keep this place going?
We have a new fuel cell system half a mile from here.
This alien creature could be hiding there.
No, we checked that an hour ago.
I'd give your arm a rest, if I were you.
Yes, we're not likely to run away.

You don't like violence, do you, Keeler? Not like your friend. What are you, a scientist? Botanist, perhaps. Is that it? Were you sent here to identify the pod? Surely you understand the implications of what I'm saying?
We know what we're doing.
I wish I could believe you.
Shut up, shut up!
You remember what happened to Winlett. Well, things are getting out of control and you don't know how to handle it. If you release us, then we can fight it together.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Stevenson and Scorby enter.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, for God's sake let's get out of here quickly before that monster thing comes back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby gives Keeler the insulated box and takes the gun.

Dialogue.Line: Stop panicking. Tie him up. Tim him up.
Rope. Excuse me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler ties Stevenson's hands behind his back, then his feet. Meanwhile, the Krynoid is on the move.

Dialogue.Line: You can say your goodbyes now, Doctor.
You're not going to shoot them in cold blood?
Why not? No, I've got a better idea. Come here, miss.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby pulls Sarah to her feet.

Dialogue.Line: Where are you taking her?
Sit down! Come on, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby hustles Sarah out of the door.

Dialogue.Line: Scorby! Scorby! Scorby!
Take us to the power plant.
I don't know what you mean.
Come on, don't try to be funny. You checked it an hour ago. Now, come on, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler follows with the container and a rucksack.
The Doctor and Stevenson are back to back, trying to untie their ropes.

Dialogue.Line: It's hopeless.
Nothing's hopeless. All we have to do is think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby fixes a device to part of the generator while Keeler ties Sarah to a pipe.

Dialogue.Line: What's that thing, Scorby?
This power system provides energy for the whole camp. There are wires running from here to every building. So we don't need to dig a hole after all. We just obliterate them. A real fireworks display.
That's murder. Cold-blooded murder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ankles tied together, the Doctor hops over to where some hurricane lamps are hanging from the ceiling. He uses his head to unhook one and let it smash onto the floor. Then he kneels down by the broken glass.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, quick, get over here. And keep still. I don't want to sever a blood vessel. Okay?
Right.
It is, it's murder. It is cold-blooded murder!
Look, you do exactly as you're told or you go up with it, Arnold.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler goes back to Sarah.

Dialogue.Line: He doesn't have to kill us. You've got the pod.
There, that should do it. That bomb will set off a fault in the system that'll blow the whole camp to smithereens, leaving no trace whatsoever. It's ingenious, don't you think?
No! No! I can't let you do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler tries to fight Scorby, but gets caught in a neck lock.

Dialogue.Line: It's too lake, Keeler. I've started the countdown. Now, let's get out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You shouldn't have long to wait. Ten minutes at the outside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Stevenson are free.

Dialogue.Line: Contact the main base on the radio.
Right.
See if they can intercept that aeroplane.
What about the Krynoid?
We'll just have to take a chance on that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Sarah!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An aeroplane motor starts up.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, main base. Hello, main base. Can you hear me? Over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krynoid bursts in and attacks Stevenson. The Doctor sees the aeroplane take off.
Antarctica is here played by Buckland Quarry. Sarah wakes to the sound of a caterpillar-tracked vehicle approaching. One man in an orange parka gets out, followed by two in whites.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The group go over to Sarah.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right? Look, we're from South Bend. These marines got me through. We heard the explosion. What happened?
The Doctor. Where's the Doctor?
It's all right, I'm a doctor. Doctor Chester. Look, we're going to take care of you. Don't worry.
No, no, you don't understand. He's trying to reach the camp. We've got to find him. Doctor!
Look, hang about. Take it easy.
Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah leads the men off. Then she spots something.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is lying face down, half covered in snow.

Dialogue.Line: Help me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They roll him over.

Dialogue.Line: He's alive.
Good morning.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby and Keeler enter the room that leads into the one with the plants. There is a desk, and filing cabinets here.

Dialogue.Line: Must be in the greenhouse. Mister Chase? Mission accomplished.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase comes in from tending his plants.

Dialogue.Line: Well? Open it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby obeys. Keeler is keeping well back.

Dialogue.Line: Astounding. I can scarcely believe it.
I wouldn't touch it.
Why not?
Well, there was this other pod, and one of the expedition apparently got infected by it.
Yes, so I heard. What happened exactly?
It was all very strange. He went mad and killed somebody.
Yeah, they told us the pod took him over in some way.
Oh. What became of this other pod?
It was destroyed. We had to blow the whole place to smithereens plus everyone in it.
What a pity. I could have had two pods.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A knock at the door.

Dialogue.Line: Come.
Mister Dunbar, sir.
Ah, come in, Dunbar. It's all right. These are the two men who brought back the pod.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves leaves.

Dialogue.Line: They know of your contribution to the enterprise.
I had no idea you'd go to such terrible lengths to get it.
The destruction of the others was necessary.
Necessary?
There it is. Look at it. Like me, I imagine you couldn't wait to see it with your own eyes.
Unlike you, I can hardly bear to look at it, considering the cost.
Since you mention cost, Dunbar, you've already been well paid for your part, so keep a stiff upper lip, forget your qualms. The object has been achieved. We can all relax.
Not quite.
No?
They weren't all wiped out. That's what I came to warn you about. The Doctor and his assistant are still alive.
That's not possible.
The Doctor's meeting Sir Colin and me in two hours time.
But why should people go to such lengths to get their hands on the pod?

Greed. Greed. The most dangerous impulse in the universe. Do you realise that on this planet the pod is unique? I use the word with precision. Unique. And to some people, its uniqueness makes it valuable at any cost.
You make these two mystery men sound like fanatics.
Fanatics? Tell him. You tell him. You tell him!
These two mystery men had everything planned. They had an aeroplane, guns, even a bomb. It was organised down to the last detail. Now, if that isn't fanaticism, well, what is?
Surely you're exaggerating.
Exaggerate? Now look, I was there. We were nearly killed!
Be calm. Be calm. Listen, both of you. Are you both listening to me? I think they were dangerous, but they were stooges. I believe they were working for someone else.
And if that's true, that someone else must be a complete madman.
What's more to the point is how they knew of the pod's existence. The discovery had been reported only to your department, correct?
That's correct. But Doctor, I trust you're not suggesting that information was leaked from this bureau?
Why not? Why shouldn't it be?
Doctor, how can you suggest such a thing?
In any case, what would be the gain?
Oh, money.
Money?
Yes, money. Hired thieves and murderers don't usually work for love.
Since you seem to have it all sewn up, Doctor, perhaps you can tell us where the pod is now?

I'll make a guess. Right here, in this country. Action! Action, that's what we need. If we don't find that pod before it germinates, it'll be the end of everything. Everything, you understand? Even your pension!
Very well, Doctor. You've made your point. All the facilities of this bureau will be placed at your disposal.
Thank you.
All right, Dunbar?
I'll organise anything you require, Doctor.
Good. Then organise us to the Botanic Institute, now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sarah leave the building - played by the BBC television centre - and are met by a chauffeur.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor?
Yes.
This car was ordered for you, sir.
Good. Let's go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Now he's alone, Dunbar is making a telephone call.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, Mister Chase. They're being taken care of. But I must warn you about that pod.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The limousine stops in the middle of a muddy, potholed lane. We're back at the quarry, folks.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on? Where are we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The chauffeur turns around with a gun in his hand.

Dialogue.Line: We're in a nice deserted place, Doctor.
Who do you work for?
Both of you, out. This side.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The chauffeur gets out first. The Doctor opens his door.

Dialogue.Line: Now just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor's window is wound down and he grabs the man through the empty space, pulling him against the door then pushing him away onto the ground.

Dialogue.Line: Sarah, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run before the chauffeur can pick himself and his gun up out of the mud and try to take a few shots at them, and scramble down a steep slope.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sarah hide amongst the piles of sand.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, down here. Down here, cloth-eyes. Are you blind?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The chauffeur runs down the slope and onto a pile of sand below the big hopper to look around. The Doctor distracts him by throwing a stone onto a corrugated roof, then pounces. He punches the man's lights out and they return to the limo.

Dialogue.Line: You try the boot.
Right, give us the key.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor searches the glove compartment. Sarah finds a framed print of a fritillaria in the boot.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, Doctor.
Yes?
Here.
What?
Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He reads the artist's signature.

Dialogue.Line: Amelia Ducat.
That's interesting.
Is it? Why?
Well, Amelia Ducat (French pronunciation) is only one of the world's leading flower artists.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A quaint cottage with china dogs and plates on display on a dado rail. The artist herself is a silver-haired old lady.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, yes, a perfect example. Fritillaria meleagris.
Is that the common snakes-head fritillary?
And why are you asking me?
No, I mean did you paint it, Miss Ducat. (pronounced Duket.)
The name is Ducat (Du-cah) actually. Yes, of course I painted it. I camped out on the Chilterns night after night to catch it at sunrise.
We're trying to trace the owner.
Isn't it yours?
No. We found it in a car boot.
A car boot?
A Daimler car boot.
The car is immaterial.
The driver wasn't. He tried to kill us.
Can you remember who bought this particular painting?
Well, nobody. I haven't finished it yet.
No, hang about, not that one. This one, Miss Ducat.
Common snakes-head fritillary.
Oh, that one. Oh, dear me. It was a long time ago. Now what was his name? Something like face? Mace? Lace?
Pace?
Base?
That's right. Chase! Of course. Harrison Chase the millionaire. Good lord. He never paid me!
No, the x-rays don't show any signs of activity, so
We mustn't give up, Keeler. I'm certain we're on the verge of a breakthrough.

Yes, but if we. (sighs) Mister Chase, please listen. Something weird happened in Antarctica. A man came into contact with the other pod, and according to the Doctor, he turned into an alien. Now I don't know what he meant exactly, but I believe it did happen, so please let's stop this experiment now.
No, Keeler. Dunbar's explained everything to me. Provided we take the proper precautions, there is no danger. Now, inject the pod with fixed nitrogen.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A telephone rings. Chase signals Keeler to answer it.

Dialogue.Line: Special Projects lab. Yes. Yes, he's here. Urgent call from Dunbar. Your chauffeur's in hospital.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor drives the Daimler up to an arched gateway in a stone wall.

Dialogue.Line: I hope this works.
It's worth the risk to find that pod.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor swaps his hat for the chauffeur's cap.

Dialogue.Line: How do I look?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A car horn summons the watchman from his mediaeval looking stone hut to open a door in the gates and look out. Then he opens the gates themselves and the Doctor drives though. Sarah is hiding. The Doctor stops the car part way along the drive.

Dialogue.Line: So far, so good.
Leave the car here?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk through the ground until they get a view of the mansion proper.

Dialogue.Line: We're here.
What's the best way in, do you think?
The front.
Not this time.
The back?
The back. Quick, hide.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two black-clad guards with automatic weapons come strolling around a flowerbed.

Dialogue.Line: Let's brazen it out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sarah walk across the lawn.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, you! Halt, or I'll fire!
Just act natural.
I am.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They start to run just before the guard opens fire, and dash through a side gate to an inner garden with a cloverleaf pond, through to another walled garden.

Dialogue.Line: Act natural, he says.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are stopped in the arboretum by Scorby.

Dialogue.Line: Hold it.
Get our hands up.
Hello, Doctor. How nice of you to come. Over here! I've got them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two guards come running.

Dialogue.Line: That's right, grab us. We're very dangerous.
You're full of good ideas, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sarah are brought in at gunpoint.

Dialogue.Line: Some visitors, Mister Chase.
So, the meddling Doctor. You lead a charmed life. You arrive without a chauffeur, not even a touch of frostbite.
How do you do. Have you met Miss Smith? She's my best friend.
Is she? And still beautifully intact, I see.
I try my best, under the circumstances.
And this is Mister Scorby. I don't know his first name. And these two gentlemen
Yes, thank you, Doctor, we are acquainted.
How nice. Hand over the pod.

After all the inconvenience I've been put to? Oh no, Doctor. Perhaps you didn't know, but in this house is assembled the greatest collection of rare plants in the world. When the pod flowers, I shall achieve the crowning glory of my life's work.
Take care. I notice a little greenfly here and there.
Your envy is understandable, Doctor. However, as I propose to have you both executed
Why? We haven't harmed you.
Be reasonable, Sarah. What choice has he got? We keep interfering.
Exactly, Doctor. However, before you die you will be granted a unique privilege. The last things you will ever see will be my beautiful plants. Please come this way.
(sotto) Look, what are you playing
Come on, on your way.
And the west wing was completed by Sir Bothwell Chase just before his execution in 1587.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They enter.

Dialogue.Line: This plant laboratory is unique, Doctor. It makes the Botanical Institute look like a potting shed.
Are we near the end? I do so hate guided tours.
Here we treat our green friends as patients. If they're puny, we build them up. If they're sick, we give them succour.
I've heard of flower power, but that is ridiculous.
You've heard of the theory that irregular light patterns can affect the senses of so-called mindless things?
Oh yes, like Scorby here.
Enjoy yourself while you can, Doctor.
Where's Keeler?
He's engaged in important and isolated research.
On the pod?
What else?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Keeler is watching the pod through a magnifying glass.

Dialogue.Line: Your coffee, sir. Two lumps, isn't it?
It's happening.
What is?
There's a floccose path forming on the pericarp.
There's a what, sir?
It's alive! It's growing! Go and fetch Mister Chase. Tell him it's urgent.
Hurry up, Hargreaves!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is admiring a palm tree.

Dialogue.Line: All right, that's enough.
Come on, move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go down some steps.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, hold it there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase is adjusting tones on his big sound mixer table.

Dialogue.Line: The hymn of the plants. I composed it myself. People say that you should talk to plants. I believe that. Just as I believe they also like music.
Got to get out of here.
(mutters)
What?
I said, the music's terrible!
Shut up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase turns the volume down.

Dialogue.Line: Now I shall play you my requiem. My Floriana Requiem, dedicated to Linnaeus.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More excruciating tones.

Dialogue.Line: You know, Doctor, I could play all day in my green cathedral.
Mister Chase.
Oh, go away. Can't you see Mister Chase is busy?
It's Mister Keeler. Something's happening to that pod!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase stops his noise.

Dialogue.Line: Why are you shouting, Hargreaves?
Would you go to the annex, please?
Yes, right. Take these people away. I imagine they won't mind a few minutes delay before they die.
All right, move.
What is it?
I thought you should see this.
Have you injected fixed nitrogen?
Fifteen grams. Careful. I shouldn't get too close.
There can't be any danger yet.
Don't forget it's alien.
More nitrogen.
No, I don't think that would be wise, Mister Chase.
I make the decisions. Inject another fifteen grams.
Where are you taking us, Scorby?
I shouldn't worry, Doctor. It's strictly a one way journey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor dodges through one of a series of small archways. Sarah grabs Scorby's gun arm.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor kicks the gun out of Scorby's hand then punches him, grabs his head and twists it. There's a cracking sound.

Dialogue.Line: Come along, Sarah.
But

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby isn't dead. He gets up clutching his throat. Sarah pauses to close a decorative iron gate after they run through it.

Dialogue.Line: We've got to warn Sir Colin.
Right. Let's get out and phone him.
Got a two P piece?
Yeah.
Good. You're going to phone him. I must get another look at that pod. Let's get you over the wall first.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby picks up his gun.

Dialogue.Line: Guards!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Three guards arrive.

Dialogue.Line: They got away. We've got to find them. You two that way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Sarah run up onto a terrace above a formal garden, running along the main wall.

Dialogue.Line: You men there cover sector nine!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor looks down the tall ivy covered wall. Meanwhile, the searchers meet at a statue of Queen Victoria.

Dialogue.Line: Spread out, you idiots.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has found some rope and he ties it around Sarah's waist.

Dialogue.Line: Come on.
Listen, you be careful of Chase. If he catches you.
Shush.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The lines between the pod's sections are even bigger. Keeler is cowering in a corner.

Dialogue.Line: Remarkable. It almost grows before my eyes. Where's your enthusiasm, Keeler? Don't you realise we face a moment of history?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor lowers Sarah down the inner curtain wall and she unties herself. The Doctor hides the rope in a nearby clipped yew and heads back to the house. A twig breaks and Sarah freezes. A guard grabs her from behind.

Dialogue.Line: One word out of you and you're a dead little girl, understand? So near yet so far.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard whistles and another comes out of the trees.

Dialogue.Line: You didn't think you'd get away with it, did you? Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor makes his way through the mansion. Scorby meets the guards by the building.

Dialogue.Line: Found her in the woods. She must have got over the wall.
And the other one?
No sign of him.
Where's the Doctor? Mister Chase isn't going to be very pleased with you. Come on. Keep looking!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby takes Sarah into the mansion.
The Doctor jumps down through the skylight. Chase lets go of Sarah's arm as the Doctor knocks out Scorby, smashing a chair over his back then picking up the gun.

Dialogue.Line: What do you do for an encore, Doctor?
I win.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs Sarah and they run from the room, locking the door behind them. Chase hammers on it.

Dialogue.Line: Open this door! Guards! Guards!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby gets out of the fireplace.

Dialogue.Line: Why am I surrounded by idiots! Guards!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krynoid tendril is flailing around, looking for something to latch on to. It finds Keeler.

Dialogue.Line: Argh! My arm! My arm!
Keeler! It's happened.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard runs in.

Dialogue.Line: What's up?
The Doctor and the girl. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby and the guard leave.

Dialogue.Line: Get in there and hide. I'll be as quick as I can.
You can't tackle them single-handed.
Why not? I've got a pistol.
But you'd never use it.
True, but they don't know that, do they.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah backs into a small stone archway.
Keeler's skin is already green. He starts to undress.

Dialogue.Line: Amazing.
My whole body's changing. Look at my arm. Get me to a hospital, please.
Don't be ridiculous. We'll look after you here.
Do something. You must do something.
It's incredible. Absolutely unique.
For pity's sake, help me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby follows the Doctor through the mansion. Meanwhile, Hargreaves the butler enters and sees all the broken glass.

Dialogue.Line: What's all this? Oh sir, I hear Mister Keeler
Mister Keeler is not very well.
Mister Keeler!
We must get him over to the cottage where we can look after him properly.
What happened, sir?
Don't ask questions, just do it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the guards run past Sarah's hiding place, Hargreaves and Chase half-carry Keeler out of the main house.

Dialogue.Line: Bear up, Keeler.
Nobody move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He puts the gun down and goes over to the empty pod. Scorby enters behind him.

Dialogue.Line: How predictable. The criminal returns to the scene of the crime.
I see the pod's burst. Was anyone in the way?
Yeah, Keeler. Very clumsy of him. Where's the girl?
You're working for a madman, Scorby, you know that?
He pays well. And when it comes to money, Mister Chase and I are of the same religion.
Franklin Adams, 1881 to 1960. American humourist.
The quotes are over, Doctor. Miss Smith'll never get out of this place alive, and neither will you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby puts the Doctor's gun in his pocket.

Dialogue.Line: Now, this way. And this time don't try anything.
You know
Not anything!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves unlocks a small white-washed thatched cottage and they carry Keeler inside.
Scorby pushes the Doctor into a containing a lot of dustbins.

Dialogue.Line: Turn around.
Can't we talk this over, Scorby?
You're getting a bit unsteady on your feet, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As he pushes him into the dustbins, knocking the breath out of him.

Dialogue.Line: You're pushing your luck, Scorby.
Take a seat, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby goes over to a machine with a hopper and conveyer belt leading to a large toothed crusher made of giant cogwheels.

Dialogue.Line: You see our little machine, Doctor?
Looks as if it's got possibilities.
Oh yes, it has. Distinct possibilities. Did you know we made our own compost?
Quite right. Always put back in the soil what you take out.
Just what Mister Chase says. He never wastes anything that can be used to fertilise his plants. Anything.
That's very commendable.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby takes a machine gun from a guard and turns on the machine. The two crushing cogs turn.

Dialogue.Line: It's got a very healthy appetite, Doctor. Tie him up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Night has fallen. Sarah comes out of her hiding place. Tied down to the cottage bed, Keeler is now mostly plant.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening? What have you done?
It's for your own good. You mustn't move.
You can't keep me here. I need medical attention! Look at me.
The rate of increase is astonishing. Remarkable, Keeler. Protein absorption from the animal, of course.
What animal?
Your own body. We shall have to give you some food soon.
Chase, stop behaving like a maniac and get me to hospital.
Don't be ridiculous. That would ruin everything. Together, we could be on the verge of a great scientific discovery. We must observe the process carefully.
Hargreaves, don't listen to him. This is murder.
I'm sure Mister Chase is right, sir. And it's for your own good.
You're changing into a plant, Keeler. You're privileged. Think of it, a marvellous new species of plant. I shall need some equipment to monitor this experiment.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase and Hargreaves leave.

Dialogue.Line: Chase!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah sees the two men come out.

Dialogue.Line: He might be right, sir. It could be dangerous.
Everything will be all right, Hargreaves, just as long as we keep him in there.
Very good, sir.
Ah, there you are, Mister Chase. We've got the Doctor. I've locked him in the compost room.
Good. No sign of the girl?
No, not yet. We've got all the exits covered. She won't get far.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone rings. Hargreaves puts down a microscope and goes to answer it.

Dialogue.Line: General laboratory. What? Oh, hold on. It's for you, sir. Says it's urgent. Main gate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase takes the telephone.

Dialogue.Line: Chase. Amelia Ducat? Why'd you let her past the main gate?
Sorry, sir. Miss Ducat insists on seeing you. Says you owe her money. Well that's what she says, sir.
Well get rid of her. I'm in the middle of some very important work and I can see no one. Is that clear?
I've told her all about that, Mister Chase, but she's very, er, persistent. She's mentioned something about lawyers, sir.
Lawyers? (covers the handset) Man's a fool. Why am I surrounded by idiots?
Wouldn't it be better to see her, Mister Chase, and avoid any fuss?
It might, and it might not. (into telephone) Have someone bring her up to the library.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah sneaks in, and hears noises upstairs. She climbs the stairs to the bedroom.

Dialogue.Line: Don't be frightened. You should be glad. After all, it might have been you.
Keeler? What have they done to you?
Disgusting, isn't it. Aren't you scared?
No, I'm not scared. Why are they keeping you here?
Chase. Chase owns me body and soul. Body. This must be how Winlett changed. You saw him at the base, didn't you. What was it like? You've got to tell me.
I'm going to find the Doctor. He knows more about this than anyone else. Now, do you know where he is?
I might. Let me loose and we'll go together.
I can't.
I won't harm you.
You mightn't mean to, but you would.
You're as bad as Chase and the others. You want me to die! You want me to die! You want me to die!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah hides in a cupboard and Hargreaves enters with a plate of food.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Keeler, try not to distress yourself. Mister Chase ordered this meal for you, sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Amelia is sitting by a roaring log fire, puffing on a cigarillo, when Chase enters.

Dialogue.Line: Good evening, Miss Ducat.
Good evening, Mister Chase. I'm sorry to have insisted on seeing you at this hour.
Not at all. It's a great pleasure, indeed an honour, to see you again.
I was visiting Lady Chandley nearby. Painting a rare hibiscus in her conservatory.
Ah yes, the Venezuelan gobbo. I have several of the species.
Of course, your collection of plants is unrivalled. Even the short safari from the gate is simply packed with interest.
What a shame you should come in the autumn. In high summer, ah.
Even so, I think I could set up my easel here to good purpose.
At any other time I'd be very happy for you to do so, but just at the moment I have some very pressing business.
What a pity. Never mind. The real reason for my coming won't take up much of your time.
Yes, it seems I neglected to pay you for a painting I had from you.
Yes.
I offer you my humblest apologies.
Seven hundred and fifty guineas.
Guineas?
Plus inflation. Shall we say a round thousand?
Pounds.
Done.
I'll write you a cheque now.
Magnificent house you have here, Mister Chase.
Yes, it is rather fine, isn't it. Most of it was built during the Wars of the Roses. Charmingly named, but rather a bloodthirsty period in history, I always think.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby enters.

Dialogue.Line: Do you want to start the (pause as he sees Amelia) recycling experiment, Mister Chase?
No. I want to see it. I'll be right there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase tears the cheque out of his book and hands it to Amelia.

Dialogue.Line: I apologise for the delay.
Thank you.
Mister Scorby will see you out.
What is this recycling experiment? Sounds interesting.
Yes, I'm afraid it's something we're keeping rather quiet about just for the moment. Within these grounds there are several private projects going on.
Oh.
This way, madam.
Goodbye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the cottage Hargreaves leaves Keeler after he has been fed. Sarah comes out of the cupboard and leaves too.
The giant cogwheels are still turning when Chase enters.

Dialogue.Line: So sorry to have kept you waiting.
Not at all, not at all.
I do hope you haven't been bored.
Oh no, I've been watching your little toy. It's most efficient.
Yes, isn't it. The problem is keeping it stocked up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase turns the machine off.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, at the moment it's working on an empty stomach.
The next time it starts, we must give it something to bite on. You've noticed how lush the grounds are?
Oh, yes.
This is the secret. We put everything into the grinder. Every scrap of food and garden waste, lots of other things. Provided they're organic.
I'm sure you're noted for your tidiness. How is Keeler?
Dear Arnold. A brilliant researcher and a dedicated botanist. And now, properly nurtured, he can be of inestimable value to science.
Nurtured. You don't mean to say you've been feeding him?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah hides behind a suit of armour as Scorby shows Amelia through a door.

Dialogue.Line: It is a fascinating house. The mixture of styles is charming. This corridor must be early 16th century, is it not?
I'm sorry, history isn't my strong point. Would you mind coming this way, please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby walks off round a corner and a guard meets him.

Dialogue.Line: We've covered the south and west sections. There's no sign of the girl.
Yes, all right, thank you. (to Amelia) Sorry, we're just doing a bit of a security exercise. Would you excuse me a moment? A word in your ear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby leads the guard away. Back around the corner...

Dialogue.Line: Psst! Miss Ducat! Please.
My dear child, are you all right?
That man Scorby mustn't see me. I'm trying to find the Doctor.
What's happening?
Will you tell Sir Colin Thackeray at the World Ecology Bureau that we've found the pod but we're trapped here. Please?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby appears.

Dialogue.Line: Were you talking to someone?
Talking?
I thought I heard voices.
That must have been me. I'm always talking to myself. It's old age, you know. Happens to us all. Er, this is the way out, is it not?
Er, yeah, just go straight

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has been tied up by a guard and put on the conveyor belt feet first.

Dialogue.Line: Right, get out.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The guard leaves.

Dialogue.Line: I shall set the machine on automatic control, which means it will start up again in a few minutes time. Your death will be agonising, Doctor, but mercifully quick.
What can I say?

Blood and bone contain the most valuable nitrogen elements. Just think. After shredding, your remains will pass automatically through my compost acceleration chamber and within twenty five minutes you will be pumped into the garden to become part of nature's grand design.
I still can't think of anything to say.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Amelia walks up to a parked car. One man gets out and opens the door for her.

Dialogue.Line: Very kind. There we are.
Well, what happened?
You were quite right, Sir Colin. The girl and the Doctor have run into trouble.
And did Chase suspect anything?
I think not. The debt for my picture was a splendid excuse.
You saw the Doctor?
No, but I saw Miss Smith. They've found the pod but they're both trapped in the house.
So Chase is behind this, after all.
Well, it would seem so. What are you going to do to help them?
We'd better alert the Doctor's friends at UNIT. This is getting too big for us.
No, wait. Let me go in alone.
You'll never get past the gate.
Yes, I will. They know me already.
What do you mean?
I've made a terrible mistake, Sir Colin. It's my duty to try and save the situation.
I don't understand.
Give me half an hour. If I'm not back by then, return to London and contact UNIT.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves enters with another plate of protein.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Mister Keeler

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But Keeler is now fully Krynoid. Hargreaves drops the plate and flees. The plant breaks the ropes and gets out of the bed.
The conveyor is starting to move the Doctor towards the grinders when Sarah enters.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Quick, Sarah, the button!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But she starts at the wrong end of the control box, and speeds things up instead.

Dialogue.Line: Not that button, the other one!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She stops the conveyer and the back of the hopper opens as she leaps in to untie the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Oh, Sarah.
What?
It would have been such a waste!
I warned you not to go too far. You must abandon the experiment, destroy that abomination.
The search for knowledge knows no boundaries. This is the most valuable study in plant biology ever made. Nothing will stop me now. I will cultivate the Krynoid.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves bursts in.

Dialogue.Line: Mister Chase! Mister Chase, that thing in the cottage, it's a monster! It's breaking loose.
What?
The ropes, they're not going to hold it.
You mean that horror could be roaming around?
It could be in the grounds by now.
I'm going for help. If that thing's free it will kill us all.
I would prefer it if you kept your mouth shut.
No, it's all gone far enough. I'm going for help.
You won't get past the guards.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dunbar produces a gun.

Dialogue.Line: We'll see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Dunbar leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Scorby! Get Dunbar!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Scorby chases Dunbar through the various courtyards and outbuildings of the estate, the Doctor and Sarah go to the bedroom.

Dialogue.Line: It's gone!
Yes, but where?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Downstairs, the Doctor takes a sword from over the fireplace before they leave.
Scorby and the guards arrive, and start shooting, distracting the Krynoid away from the Doctor and Sarah.

Dialogue.Line: Run!
Come on, don't waste your bullets!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby and the guards follow them.

Dialogue.Line: Block the door.
Yeah, come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They push a two seater settee in front of the door.

Dialogue.Line: Quietly!
How do you do it, Doctor? You should be compost by now.
We'll all be compost if we don't keep away from that Krynoid.
Krynoid? Is that what that thing is?
Yes. It used to be called Keeler. Remember Keeler, your friend? Now do you see what we're up against?
That's Keeler?
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby's walkie-talkie beeps. He answers it.

Dialogue.Line: Yeah.
Scorby, what was that firing?
That Krynoid thing, Mister Chase. It's got us trapped in the cottage.
You idiots. Listen to me. Whatever happens, it must not be harmed. Is that clear?
Mister Chase, you don't understand. It's eight foot high and its already killed Dunbar.
I don't care who it's killed. People are replaceable, Scorby. The Krynoid is unique. It must not be damaged in any way. That's an order.
Mister Chase, I am not getting through to you
Give it to me. Chase, try and understand one thing. The Krynoid is an uncontrollable carnivore that's getting bigger and more powerful by the minute. Now (beep) Chase? Chase! Arrogant fool.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes to the window.

Dialogue.Line: Where is it now?
I don't know.
What are we going to do?
Is it going to keep on growing? How big's it going to get?
Oh, about the size of Saint Paul's Cathedral. After that, it'll multiply itself a thousand-fold until it takes over your entire planet.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A tentacle smashes through a rear window.

Dialogue.Line: Get back! Stay back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby dashes up the stairs, shooting. Sarah uses an axe from the log basket but is pushed away by the tentacle. The Doctor jabs with his sword and it eventually withdraws.

Dialogue.Line: You don't scare us, Keeler. You hear? You don't scare us! (to Scorby) Do you think he believed us?
The human was Keeler. Now us. Now belongs.
It speaks!
It can think.
You, Doctor. Come out now. Join us.
You seem to have been singled out for special attention, Doctor.
It's afraid he'll find a way to destroy it.
Yes. It does seem to sense my knowledge of alien species, particularly the Krynoid.
Send the Doctor to us. Your lives will then be spared.
You'd better think of something pretty quickly, hadn't you, Doctor.
Oh, Scorby, take no notice of it. I've heard that one before.
It sounds a pretty fair deal to me. How about it, Doctor? You'd lay down your life for others, wouldn't you?
Not to save your skin. Not after what you did to us.
This is different.
Why is it different?
He'd be sacrificing himself for you, for all of us.
What, because you're involved, it's your life
Excuse me! Would you mind if I said something?
And you'd better listen, because nobody else knows how to fight that creature.
Hear this, humans. You have till daybreak to deliver the Doctor.
Why wait? Why not now?
Scorby, if I die, you die.
I'll take a chance on that.
There is no chance! By daybreak the Krynoid'll be large enough to crush this entire cottage to rubble. If I could get outside there'd be some hope for all of us.
Why don't I just throw you out?
It would make no difference! We need a bomb. Scorby, could you make a bomb? Could you make a fire bomb of some kind?
What for?
To distract the Krynoid while we all slip away.
Molotoff cocktail?
Yes, that's a good idea.
Okay, leave it to me. You keep watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby goes upstairs and the Doctor stands guard by the broken window.
At the World Ecology Bureau in London, Thackeray is hanging on the phone while Amelia Ducat smokes another of her cigarillos.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, come on. Not exactly rushing themselves, are they.
Perhaps we should have gone back into the grounds?
Too dangerous. I wonder what has happened to Dunbar?
Mmm. Of course, there were these armed men running about.
Must have been quite terrifying.
Not a bit. I enjoyed it. I like a little excitement. Besides, I have some wartime experience, you know. Oh yes. I was a sergeant in the ATS. Manned an ack-ack gun at Folkestone.

Indeed. (into phone) Yes, yes. This is Sir Colin Thackeray. I am aware that the Brigadier is in Geneva. I must speak to a senior officer. This is a matter of national security. Yes, national security.
Invent a codeword. They love that. What about Operation Nuthouse?
What, Major Beresford? Well, right, get him down here fast! Thank you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Thackeray puts the phone down.

Dialogue.Line: Bravo.
What a nit-wit.
That's the stuff to give 'em. After all, our taxes pay for these wretched civil servants and you can never get hold of them when you want them, can you.
I'm a civil servant, Miss Ducat.
Then you know exactly what I mean, of course.
Of course. Well now, I think it's time you ran along and got some sleep.
Oh, I'm not sleepy.
Thank you very much for all you've done.
Not at all. I do hope you'll be able to get some help to the Doctor and that dear child, that little girl
Yes.
Before it's too late.
We'll do our best. Yes, thank you.
Consider me available for any future assignments, Sir Colin.
Oh, yes, yes, I will, yes.
Au revoir.
Thank you very much.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Morning, and Chase is getting a camera ready.

Dialogue.Line: Botanical history, Hargreaves. These'll be the first pictures ever taken of an alien organism.
That thing, sir. You will be careful, won't you?
Why? I have nothing to fear from the Krynoid.
Scorby, can I rely on you?
For the moment, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby finishes putting a wick into a partly filled milk bottle.

Dialogue.Line: I'll check the position of the Krynoid.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby goes upstairs. The Doctor gestures the guards to move the settee from the door.

Dialogue.Line: Clear this door. Quietly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase walks along a tall hedge then sees the Krynoid towering over the cottage.

Dialogue.Line: Stand by.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He lights the wick then throws the bottle out of the bedroom window at the Krynoid. The Doctor runs out of the front door.

Dialogue.Line: The fools.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Krynoid lumbers after the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Okay, it worked. It's gone after him.
Okay, let's go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby, Sarah and the guards leave. The Doctor sprints to the driveway where he left the Daimler, climbs in and drives away.

Dialogue.Line: Chase! Any sign?
No.
Hargreaves, come here. Where's Chase?
Mister Chase has gone out to take some photographs.

Photographs? What's he playing at? Well, listen. I've posted lookouts but they're not going to stay very long. Get over to the workshop, help get some timber. We've got to board up all these ground floor windows.
If you say so.
Well, I heard the car move off, so the Doctor must have got away.
He's no fool, your friend. He's escaped, we're still trapped.
But he went to get help. You know he went to get help. You were there.
Sure.
Listen. The Doctor's not just concerned about saving his own skin. He's risked his life before for others. Unlike you, he has principles.
Oh, yeah? Well you listen to me. Now there's just the two of us, so you've got to rely on me. So don't push your luck, because if you do, I'll start again exactly where I left off. Understood?

You're as mad as Chase, Scorby. Other people don't matter. All these guards, all these guns, it's just a big game to you, isn't it? Gives you a sense of power. You're not complete unless you've got a gun in your hand.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase finds a good view of the Krynoid by an ivy covered tree, and starts taking his picture. The plant moves closer, and he has to angle the camera ever higher until he realises just how close it has got.

Dialogue.Line: No. No, not me. I want to help. Keeler, you know me. I want to help you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The bulk of the Krynoid blocks out the light.
The Doctor parks the Daimler in a No Parking space and runs inside the WEB.

Dialogue.Line: Sir Colin, you do understand that without clear evidence I will not mount a raid on someone's private property.
I agree. Without further evidence, we're stuck.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor bursts in with a piece of paper in his hand, followed by a official.

Dialogue.Line: You cannot go in. Sir Colin is in conference.
Out, out, out.
Really!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slams the door in his face.

Dialogue.Line: What have you decided, Major Beresford?
Doctor, I've been telling Sir Colin that without the proper authority I will not mount a raid on someone's private property.
Waffle! Waffle, waffle, waffle! Where's the Brigadier?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone beeps and the Doctor answers it.

Dialogue.Line: He's busy.
He's in Geneva.
I'm deputising.
And you can't act without authority.
Look, I'm in a very difficult position. What exactly is going on down there?
Revolution's going on down there.
Revolution. Come now, Doctor. Are you choosing your words with care?
Somehow the Krynoid can channel its power to other plants. All the vegetation on this planet is about to turn hostile.
You mean like aggressive rhubarb?
Yes, aggressive rhubarb.
What about homicidal gooseberries?
You are joking, of course, Doctor.
No, I'm not joking. Read this report. I just snatched it from your secretary. Go on, read it. Aloud.
Gardener aged fifty five found strangled in rose arbour. Agricultural worker found strangled in kale field.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor snatches the paper and gives it to Beresford.

Dialogue.Line: You.
Thirty two year old woman strangled in a garden maze.
This bit.
And all within a mile of Chase's estate.
Well, that's it, then.
Shall we get started, gentlemen?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The telephone rings. Sarah runs in from the greenhouse to answer it.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Doctor. You all right? So, what's happening?
Things are moving at last. Sir Colin's seen the light and Major Beresford's getting a laser gun team together. That should stop the Krynoid. I'm on my way back with a Sergeant Henderson.
Well, make it soon. The Krynoid's still lurking around outside the house somewhere. Scorby? Oh, don't worry, we're great friends. Well, uneasy allies.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A vine clambers up the roof and rips out the telephone line.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor? Doctor? Hello? Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vines smash through the windows of the lab.
Chase is lying on his back on the grass.

Dialogue.Line: Yes. Yes. The plants must win. It will be a new world, silent and beautiful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby enters with some planks of wood.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter with you? What are you doing down there?
I was talking to the Doctor, the line went dead and those vines smashed the panes.
Oh, come on.
No, look, they are getting thicker.
Yeah, you're right. They're only plants.
So how did the glass break?
How am I supposed to know? Maybe it was the ghost of Sir Bothwell Chase. He's supposed to haunt this place.
Why can't you believe me?
Because it doesn't make sense, that's why.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: More breaking glass.

Dialogue.Line: It's the Krynoid. It's controlling them.
How can it?
I don't know. The Doctor will, and he's on his way back. Yes, that surprises you, doesn't it, even more than the Krynoid. But it's true. Have a little faith, Scorby.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves enters.

Dialogue.Line: Scorby, all the guards have left. I think they've made a run for it.
Typical. Just like a bunch of women.
And I heard screams from the west garden but I didn't go out.
Let's take a look.
Look, we'd better stay put.
He just said he heard a scream. Obviously someone is in trouble.
Well, what can we do with that thing roaming about out there?
What was that you just said about women?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sarah and Scorby find a man wrapped in a plant.

Dialogue.Line: He's been strangled by the vine.
Oh come on, Doctor. Where are you?
I've taken some fascinating photographs. Quite fascinating.
Look, we're in real trouble. These plants are taking over.
And why not? It's their world. We're merely parasites. I must get these photographs developed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase leaves.

Dialogue.Line: He's out of his head. He's really gone.
He must have been gone for years, if you ask me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Chase is sitting cross-legged on a metal walkway amongst the tropical lushness, with his 'music' playing in the background.

Dialogue.Line: Listen to me, my beautiful friends. Listen to me. A new era dawns upon the Earth. You will be restored to your position of dominance.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hargreaves closes the door to the greenhouse just before Scorby and Sarah enter.

Dialogue.Line: Hargreaves, where's Chase now?
He's in there. I believe he's talking to his plants.
I don't care about that. Get out of the way.
Chase!
We shall have perfection. The world will be as it should have been from the beginning, a green paradise.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Scorby turns off the 'music' and goes over to Chase.

Dialogue.Line: Chase, listen to me.
A harmony of root, stem, leaf, flower.
Chase!
It's no good. He can't hear you.
What's the matter with him?
He's not himself.
He's in some sort of a trance.
Chase, you've got to listen to me. If we don't do something, we're going to be trapped here. Those precious plants of yours are starting to kill people.
The time has come. Animals have ruled this planet for millions of years. Now it is our turn.
What do you mean, your turn? You're one of us, Chase.
